You know, this idea that the issue of gay rights is 'off-limits' to critique simply because it could be construed as "slander", or because some gay people take it so personally, or because a limited group of extreme detractors within the broader body of people opposed to gay marriage make personal attacks from time to time is sorta silly.
 
 One would think that if gay pride folks were so concerned with being slandered or with hate being spread in forums like this, they would actually try to lobby the creators of these fora to take down such places where the supposed hate is supposedly spread. It's pretty obvious that any form of debate on this by detractors is going to be misrepresented as hate speech simply on the basis that it's a disagreement. But it seems that those who feel so slandered by this would rather focus their efforts on complaining about it IN the very forum that serves as a vehicle FOR that "slander" rather than trying to do anything substantive to take such hate-speech away. Why bitch about a form of free speech on one hand when on the other you seem uninclined to really try to change things? It seems that in general, people know that gay rights is indeed a legitimate debateable topic and that debating it doesn't constitute "hate" or "oppression." If they didn't, we wouldn't have places like this to debate it. The only reason that debate would be a personal attack is if gay people take it that way. I think anyone doing an honest assessment of the threads here will see that it's quite rare for anyone to come in and and make personal direct statements like "you are going to hell 'cause you're gay" or "you are immoral" or "you are like pedophiles." That doesn't happen much. When they do come up, it's usually over the behavioral aspect or the sake of limited analogy. 
 
 Another point . . .
 
 There's no way to substantively argue things like "psychological damage" by CWA or other groups--this is something that, if the damage exists, it's not measureable. At this point we're in the realm of speculation. One can give opinions all day about whether or not statements can "lead" to oppression, but these are all non-concrete issues. They are ultimately unprovable because it involves matters of perception and assumptions without solid evidence. It's ultimately going to be your unproven opinion to say that groups like CWA are causing harm by their statements.
